Chiricahua Apache Text 34. The Woman Shaman as told by Sam Kenoi They were moving about in wild country. (34.1) Dá'áko' naanájiséná'a. Tł'éé'go, nnáheezáͅná'a. Nédaajiłdziná'a. 'Ákogo, dáłeeyá, náádaa'jinees n dilná'a. 'Ákogo łi' 'isdzání: "Nanłtło. Daagot'éí ha'shíͅda 'i n daa nahch'iͅiͅnóosééł hálíí k'égońghaał." daagołji n diná'a. They were moving about in wild country. It being night, they had stopped. They were afraid. Then, in a certain place, they had made a windbreak. Then [to] one woman: "Perform a ceremony 1 . See if perhaps any enemies are coming toward us from somewhere." they said to her. Then they sat about inside this windbreak. (34.2) 'Ákoo díí náá'nees n dilí bighe'yá naajiyeestáͅná'a. Tł'éé'go, naajiłtłoná'a. 'Iłch'áͅnájaałts'íͅíͅłná'a. Naanájałghołná'a. Náá'nees n dilí bitisá goganí ha'ágo 'ádził'iͅiͅná'a. Díí: "Doohashíͅ'iyáada; dooha'iyáada; díík'een, gózhóͅ." ji n digo náá'nees n dilí bitisá goganí ha'yágo 'ájił'iͅiͅná'a. Then they sat about inside this windbreak. At night, she performed a ceremony. She was waving her arms about. She was moving about. She did so [with] her arms somewhere over the windbreak. This: "There is nothing anywhere; There is nothing anywhere; Everywhere, it is good," She said as she did so [with] her arms somewhere over the windbreak. The white soldiers had crawled there to the windbreak. (34.3) 'I n daa siláádoí náá'nees n dilí 'áshíͅ ndaaheesdóͅóͅzná'a. Díídíí: "Dooha'yáda." ji n digo, náá'nees n dilí bitisá dashdił n diní 'i n daa hitisgóódzíͅíͅzná'a, golaatsíńshíͅ yiisiłgo. 'Ákoo, tł'éé'íyaͅaͅ, baaha'daijiyeezhoozhná'a. Dákíná goosiłná'a. The white soldiers had crawled there to the windbreak. As she said this: "There is nothing anywhere." the white men caught the wrists of the arms she had been moving about over the windbreak [and] pulled her over it. Then, because it was night, [the others] ran away from them. Only she was caught. Linguistic Notes by Harry Hoijer (34.2) Linguistic Notes 1. 'iłch'áͅnájaałts'íͅíͅłná'a 'she was waving her arms about'. 'iłch'áͅ 'from one another'; ná - 'around, in a circle' plus the 3a prog. of - ch'iͅ 'to move one's arms' [act. intr.]. 2. goganí 'her arms'. -gan 'arms'. 3. doohashíͅ'iyáada 'there is nothing anywhere'. doo-...da negative; hashíͅ 'from anywhere'; 'iyáa 'something'. (34.3) Linguistic Notes 1. ndaaheesdóͅóͅzná'a 'they had crawled there' 3rd person distrib. perf. of ni-hi- ...[si- perf.]- dóͅóͅs 'to crawl there, to that point' [act. intr.] Cf. note 32.2, §3. 2. dashdił n diní 'the arms which she had been moving about'. 3a person imp. of dah-di- ...[si- perf.]-l- n di 'to move one's hands, arms about' [mediopas.]. 3. hitisgóódzíͅíͅzná'a 'they pulled her over it'. hitis 'over it' plus 3rd person perf. with 3a object of ...[hi- perf.]- dzíͅíͅs 'to pull' [act. tr.]. Ethnological Notes Morris Opler Ethnological Note 1 This ceremony is one used to locate missing objects, missing persons, and the enemy. The shaman sings and prays and supernatural power is expected to take possession of him and move his arm in the direction of the enemy or missing object. If no enemy is near this information is communicated to the singer by his power.
